She is seeking this loan in order to stock up on herbs for boosting memory, herbs for [treating infections] and herbs for treating sexual dysfunctions so as to maximize her profit margin. This will allow Akouvi to help her husband provide for their children's education and everyday family needs.

loans.use: to buy 20 units of memory-boosting herbs, 25 units of anti-inflammatory herbs and 25 units of  sexual-dysfunction herbs.

loans.name: Wunisongya  Atuliba - Biisi Group

texts.en: Matilda is a 53-year-old married woman with five children. She lives in Atuliba-Biisi in the Upper-East region of Ghana. Matilda is the individual seated in the middle in the front line with the hand raised in the photo. The name of Matilda’s group is 'Wunisongya Atuliba - Biisi' Group (which means "God will help you" group of Atuliba-Biisi. Matilda is engaged in petty trading; she retails plastic products at the local market. Matilda has a large customer base and is challenged by having inadequate capital. She and Wunisongya Atuliba - Biisi Group have therefore requested a loan of GHC 22,900.00 to support their businesses. Matilda’s share of the loan is GHC 1,500.00, which would help her to buy more plastic products for resale to get increased income.The success of Matilda’s business directly improves her family’s livelihood, and she looks forward to getting funded. She is very happy there is a Kiva opportunity for her. Matilda is very grateful to her Kiva lenders for the support.

loans.use: to buy more plastic products for resale to get increased income.

loans.name: Patapampa Al Progreso Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “PATAPAMPA AL PROGRESO” de la Asociación Arariwa desde hace varios años atrás y les va muy bien, ellos viven en la provincia de La Convención del distrito de Echarate en el sector de Patapampa. 
Ignaciana es una socia trabajadora y emprendedora, ella saca adelante a sus 5 hijos. Ella tiene 52 años y se dedica a la agricultura, con esta actividad aporta gastos en su hogar.
La socia cultiva frutas y nueces,  Ignaciana solicito el préstamo para comprar semillas y abono.
Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de agricultura, ganadería, venta de abarrotes y otros se dedican a trabajar en la municipalidad en diferentes áreas.
Los socios agradecen a los inversionistas de KIVA, se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en: The members have belonged to the communal bank “PATAPAMPA AL PROGRESO” of the Arariwa Association for many years, and they are doing very well. They live in the province of La Convencion of the district of Echarate in the sector of Patapampa. Ignaciana is a hardworking and enterprising woman. She supports her 5 children. She is 52 years old and works in agriculture. With this business she pays for household expenses. The member cultivates fruits and nuts. Ignaciana requested the loan to buy seeds and manure. The other members work in agriculture, animal husbandry, grocery store sales, and others work at the municipality in different areas. The members are grateful to the Kiva lenders and promise to make their payments on time.

loans.use: to buy seeds and manure.

loans.name: Azzenath

texts.en:
Azzenath is a married woman. She has 4 children. She describes herself as kind. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. She says that her biggest business challenge is inadequate working capital. 

She will use the Kes 80,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. Her business goal is to be a supplier of clothes within 5 years. She will use the anticipated profits to boost the business.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes

loans.name: Annah

texts.en: Annah is a married woman. She has three children. She describes herself as visionary. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the KES 80,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. Her business goal is to have a boutique within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will improve her living standards. This is her fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a married woman. She has three children. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be transport. She will use the KES 95,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. Her business goal is to be an importer of clothes within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will have a stable business. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to open another outlet.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes

loans.name: Fe

texts.en: Fe lives in Oroquieta City and supports her children by building houses from the ground up. She has successfully repaid her whole loan, which she used to purchase plywood, nails, and sticks for her house. She wants her daughters to get an education and escape the life of backbreaking work she has had to endure.

loans.use: to purchase plywood, nails, and sticks for her house

loans.name: Doreen

texts.en: Doreen is a married woman. She has two children. She describes herself as ambitious. She operates a retail business where she sells sugar, rice, bread, flour and other items. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in a strategic place and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the KES 70,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, bread, flour, soap and other items. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within five years.  She will use the anticipated profits to purchase additional stock.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, bread, flour, soap and other items.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is a married woman. She has four children. She operates a tailoring shop where she makes clothes. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be low stock of materials. She will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of tailoring materials. She hopes that in the future, she will own a boutique. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tailoring materials

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with two children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF in order to buy feeds, medicines and vaccines for her pigs.

She supplements this income with earnings from her rice retailing business.

Analiza dreams that one day she will be able to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed, medicines and vaccines for her pigs.

loans.name: Fedelina

texts.en:
Fedelina is a married woman with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Fedelina is 60 years old now.

Fedelina has a photography business in the Philippines. Fedelina requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy photo film, frames, and other supplies for her business.

Fedelina has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, Fedelina would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy photo film, frames, and other supplies for her business.

loans.name: Gaspar

texts.es:
Gaspar es un hombre de 32 años de edad, es casado con una linda familia de siete hijos de las edades entre 5 y 12 años de edad esta familia vive en una comunidad de San Andrés Semetabaj.
Gaspar con el afán de obtener sus ingresos y sacar adelante a su familia trabaja como conductor de moto taxi, con esta actividad lleva l 10 años de realizarlo. Con el paso de los años su familia ha estado creciendo y con ellos las necesidades han aumentado, una de las cosas más primordiales es un terreno pues hasta el momento esta familia no cuenta con un lugar donde poder cultivar, pero una de sus dificultades  que tiene Gaspar es que carece de dinero por tal motivo solicita un préstamo para comprar una cuerda de terreno. Su gran sueño es fortalecer su negocio y mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Gaspar, 32, is married with a lovely family of 7 children ranging in age from 5 to 12. This family lives in a community in San Andrés Semetabaj.

To bring in income and provide for his family, Gaspar works as a mototaxi driver. He has been doing this work for 10 years. Over time, his family has been growing and their needs have increased. One of the most basic things is land, since so far the family has not had land to farm. One of Gaspar's challenges is that he lacks money to buy land, so he is requesting a loan to buy a 28 square meter plot of land. His big dream is to develop his business and improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy 28 square meters of land for farming.

loans.name: Kwa Ndeke Group

texts.en: The person raising her hand is Teresia. She is 57 years old, married and blessed with five children. She is a member of Kwa Ndeke group which joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in 2014 and has been trained on enterprise development and financial management. Teresia does vegetable and fruit farming.  She is borrowing from Kiva to buy water pipes for irrigation to help increase her farm output. She hopes her income will increase and thus provide better shelter and food for her family. She is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to pay well.

loans.use: to buy water pipes for irrigation that will  help increase her farm output.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en: Jessica has signed up for her membership with PMPC and requested the needed capital to start up a sari-sari store business. She is thankful for the capital that PMPC extends to a small-time loaner like her. Jessica is able to turn the tide in her favor and has made good sales these days. She wants to take advantage of the good fortune. Recently, she requested a loan to restock her store with basic commodities like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce. In the future, she hopes to have a decent home for the family.

loans.use: to restock her store with basic commodities like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en: Mwanaisha is a married woman. She has 2 children. She operates a tailoring shop where she makes clothes. She has been involved in this business for 15 years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the Kes 70,000 loan to buy more stock of tailoring materials. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tailoring materials

loans.name: Anjelina

texts.en: Anjelina is a married woman. She has eight children. She describes herself as honest. She operates a retail business where she sells flour, sugar, rice, and other items. She has been involved in this business for 12 years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the KES 51,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, rice, and flour. Her business goal is to have a bigger supermarket within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, rice, and flour.

loans.name: Rumana

texts.en: Rumana is a Kiva borrower. She has three children. She describes herself as focused. She operates a farm where she keeps dairy cows and also grows vegetables. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in a fertile area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the KES 90,000 loan to buy farm inputs. She hopes that in the future, she will have more cows. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en: Salome is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be ambitious. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes, pillows and other items. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. She will use the KES 80,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. Her business goal is to own a boutique within five years. This is her fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is 54 years old and married with five children.

She is in agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Mary Ann is borrowing PHP 9,000 through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pig.

Mary Ann has been in this business for five years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pig

loans.name: Generosa

texts.en:
Generosa is a married woman with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Generosa is 49 years old and has one child in school.

Generosa has a general store business in the Philippines. Generosa requested a PHP 8,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like bread, canned goods, home product care, and other groceries.

Generosa has been in this business for three years. In the future, Generosa would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like bread, canned goods, home product care, and other groceries

loans.name: Romulo

texts.en:
Romulo is a hardworking entrepreneur with eight children.

He has a tricycle passenger business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 50,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy wheels and spare parts for his tricycle.

Romulo industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like a fishing business.

He dreams that one day he will be able to save money to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy wheels and spare parts for his tricycle.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en: Ofelia is 55 years old and lives in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She began by selling a small amount of viand and snacks to her neighbors. She joined Paglaum Cooperative, which helped her in the capitalization of her sari-sari (small grocery) store in January of 2004. She became a member in good standing, which is why she has already received several loans. Now she is applying for 12,000 PHP to buy merchandise for her sari-sari store. She hopes that her business will continue and someday become a mini-grocery.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en: Mary Ann is a businesswoman from Calamba. She is 46 years old, married with two school-aged kids, and has expertise in selling. She runs a little sari-sari store and earns a meager income that sufficiently supports her family. Mary Ann is a full-fledged member of PMPC and has gotten several loans already. She maintains her membership in good standing without records of default. Now she has applied for a loan to restock her store with basic commodities and other consumable items. Mary Ann continues to look for better business opportunities, proof that she has the passion and the energy to make ends meet for her family.

loans.use: to restock her store with basic commodities and other consumable items.

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.en:
Gulbahor was born in 1973. She is married and has four children. Gulbahor is a very hardworking and responsible woman. She lives with her family in a rural area. Gulbahor and her husband have an agricultural business. Her husband grows crops and vegetables.

Gulbahor has been busy with animal husbandry. She feeds sheep. Gulbahor has worked in this field for more than 10 years. She is going to increase the number of sheep she feeds. She is asking for a loan of 10,000 TJS to buy sheep. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy sheep

loans.name: Medialyn

texts.en:
Medialyn is 48 years old and married with three children.

She is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Medialyn is borrowing PHP 7,000 through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs.

Medialyn has been in this business for four years and also earns additional income from food vending.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is a married woman with 1 child. She describes herself as honest. She operates a restaurant. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. 

She says that her biggest business challenge is inadequate working capital. She will use the Kes 40,000 loan to buy more stock  of ingredients for preparing food. 

She hopes that she will expand the business in the future. Her business goal is to have a big hotel within 5 years. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy more stock  of ingredients for preparing food

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es: Rosa es una mujer admirable que vive con su compañero de vida y sus 4 hijos 3 hijas de 18 y seis años y la menor de 10 meses de edad, además un varón de 12 años de edad a los que siempre busca la manera de brindar lo mejor. Ella es una mujer trabajadora que se dedica a la elaboración y venta de tortillas, lo que le permite obtener sus ingresos económicos. Rosa desea construir un cuarto en su vivienda, para mejorar la comodidad de sus hijos, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: cemento, arena, grava, ladrillo y hierro para construir un cuarto en su vivienda.
texts.en:
Rosa is an admirable woman who lives with her life companion and her four children. She has three girls, aged 18, 6 years old and the youngest is 8 months old. Plus she has a 12 year old son. She always looks for a way to provide them with the best. She is a hard-working woman who works making and selling tortillas which allows her to obtain her economic resources.

Rosa wants to construct a room in her house to increase her children's comfort. So she is requesting a loan from FUSAI to invest in cement, sand, gravel, bricks and re-bar to construct a room on her house.

loans.use: to invest in cement, sand, gravel, bricks and re-bar to construct a room on her house.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en: Imelda is a widowed woman with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Imelda is 67 years old now. Imelda has a general store business in the Philippines. Imelda requested a 5,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like bread, sugar, home care products, and other groceries. Imelda has been in this business for one year. In the future, Imelda would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like bread, sugar, home care products, and  other groceries

loans.name: Noemi

texts.en:
Noemi is 26 years old and married with two children.

Noemi works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her store like canned goods, noodles, spices, milk, coffee, drinks, eggs, bread and other snack foods.

Noemi has borrowed and paid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from food vending.

Noemi aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her store like canned goods, noodles, spices, milk, coffee, drinks, eggs, bread and other snack foods.

loans.name: Cecilia Narciza

texts.es: Cecilia tiene 49 años de edad, de estado civil soltero vive con su padre que tiene 94 años de edad, hace tres años empezó con tres juegos de sábanas visitando a sus clientes puerta a puerta con mucho esfuerzo sale de su casa muy temprano a vender sus productos. Cecilia necesita el dinero para invertir en la compra de sabanas y cobijas logrando así aumentar sus ventas y obtener mayores ingresos para poder pagar alimentación, algunas medicinas de su padre  ella aspira tener una casa propia.
texts.en: Cecilia is 49 year old, single, and lives with her father who is 94 years old. Three years ago, she began with three sets of sheets, visiting her customers door to door. With a lot of effort, she leaves home very early to sell her products. Cecilia needs money to invest in purchasing sheets and blankets, thus managing to increase her sales and obtain higher income, in order to be able to pay for food and some medicines for her father. She aspires to have her own house.

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of sheets and blankets.

loans.name: Jenilyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Jenilyn works hard to support her family.

She has a bicycle transport business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store.  Jenilyn is borrowing PHP 7000 through NWTF to buy spare parts and other materials needed for her bicycle transport business.

Jenilyn has been sustaining her business activities through a past loan from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and other materials needed in her business

loans.name: Celedonia

texts.en: Celedonia is a business woman from Oroquieta City. She wanted to finish the construction of her house, so she has asked for a loan from Paglaum MPC. The amount of the loan shall be used to pay for window grills and window glass.

loans.use: to pay for window grills and window glass

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
Cherry is running a veterinary supplies store in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She supplies animal feeds and other veterinary products to local hog growers and livestock raisers.

Her business is supported by the loan products of Paglaum MPC, where she nurtures her membership, making her one of the microfinance members.

Recently, she took a loan to purchase more stock of veterinary supplies such as animal feeds, vitamins, medicines and others.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of veterinary supplies such as animal feeds, vitamins, medicines and others.

loans.name: Norita

texts.en: Norita is 58 years old, married and has five children. Norita is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Norita requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pig. Norita has been in this business for 18 years now, and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. In the future, Norita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pig

loans.name: Caren

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Caren works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from buying and selling personal care product.  Caren is borrowing PHP 6000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food vending business such as sugar, rice, peanut, etc.

Caren has been sustaining her business activities through her past 5 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food vending business such as sugar, rice, peanut, etc.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Jane. She is 52 years old, a widow, and has four children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH-EA) in 2014 and has undergone training on enterprise and financial management.

She operates a shop to earn a living. She is borrowing from Kiva for the first time to buy more stock of sugar and cooking oil that will boost sales. She anticipates increased income, which will enable her to better cater to her family's needs.

She is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to pay well.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar and cooking oil that will boost sales.

loans.name: Mukeu Focal Area Seed Multiplication Group

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand is Hannah. She is 47 years old, married, and blessed with nine children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2014 to benefit from the trainings, especially enterprise development and financial management.

She farms kale, potato, and cabbage. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy fertilizer and manure to boost vegetable production. This will enable her to earn more income to renovate her house, pay school fees for her children, and provide them with better food.

Hannah is happy for Kiva and their lenders and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and manure

loans.name: Mireidy

texts.es:
Doña Mireidy tiene 57 años de edad, es casada y madre de 2 hijos, vive con su esposo y su hijo menor, estudiante universitario y dependiente económicamente de ellos. Trabajó por muchos años para una televisora nacional, hasta que quedo embaraza de su segundo hijo, los médicos le dijeron que era un embarazo de alto riesgo y que no debía trabajar, luego de una licencia de incapacidad que se extendió por varios meses, ya que su hijo nació prematuro, tomó la decisión de renunciar a su trabajo y dedicarse al cuido de su hijo que demandaba de cuidados especiales. Al transcurrir el tiempo y lograr estabilizar la salud de su hijo, se vio en la necesidad de propiciar un autoempleo, que le permitiera ayudar a su esposo y sacar adelante a sus hijos. Inició vendiendo helados desde su casa, productos muy reconocidos en la comunidad por tradición y calidad. Luego el dueño de la fábrica de helados situado en Tierra Blanca le ofreció hacerle una ruta y que ella se encargara de la venta y distribución de los helados. Negocio que ella aceptó,  en sociedad  con una amiga de muchos años Doña Amanda incursionó en el negocio de la venta de helados desde hace más de 5 años, ambas lograron consolidar el negocio y actualmente ella continúa buscando nuevos nichos de mercado en otros proyectos comerciales, como la preparación y venta de ceviches empacados, nueva rama de actividad en la que está dando los primeros pasos, junto a su hijo mayor. 
En cuanto a la venta de helados su principales clientes son pulperías y abastecedores de toda la provincia de Heredia. Se realiza una ruta 3 veces a la semana para la venta del producto. Mientras que en el negocio del ceviche ella sería un proveedor más del producto preparado y empacado para venderlo a una empresa consolidada llamada Lima Fish, que se encarga de vender alimentos preparados para sodas empresariales en las Zonas Franca de Heredia y Alajuela, dicha empresa es propiedad de su hijo mayor. Doña Mireidy está convencida que la calidad del producto y la experiencia que adquirió trabajando ocasionalmente con su hijo le permitiría elaborar un producto de calidad y competitivo, hasta lograr establecerse en el mercado. En el momento que inicie de lleno con la preparación de los ceviches, ella y su hijo tiene en mente crear un contrato donde defina que va ser ella la encargada de abastecer 2 de las sodas de la cartera de clientes existente. También ya tiene dispuesto como combinaría ambas actividades, ya que no piensa dejar de lado su negocio de tanto tiempo que es la venta de los helados con su socia. 
Doña Mireidy acostumbra lavar todos los desechos reciclables, los cuales entrega al hogar comunitario, dicho centros vende este material para recaudar fondos para sus servicios a la comunidad. 
Este nuevo financiamiento es la oportunidad para Doña Mireidy de incursionar en un nuevo negocio, así mismo reforzar el existente. Todo esto en busca de mejorar sus condiciones de vida, seguir apoyando a su hijo para que concluya sus estudios superiores y desde ya crear un ahorro pensando en la jubilación de su esposo y por supuesto para ella.
texts.en:
Mireidy, 57, is married and has two children. She lives with her husband and her younger son, who is a university student who depends on them financially. For many years, she worked for a national television station, but when she was pregnant with her second child, the doctors told her that it was a high-risk pregnancy and she should not work. After being on disability leave for several months, when her son was born premature, she decided to quit her job and focus on taking care of her son, who needed special care. Over time, as her son's health stabilized, she needed to find self-employment to be able to help her husband and provide for their children.

She started out selling ice cream from her home, products that were well known in the community for tradition and quality. Then, the owner of the ice cream factory in Tierra Blanca offered her a route where she would be in charge of ice cream sales and distribution. She accepted this opportunity in partnership with a longtime friend, Amanda. She started out in the ice cream sales business more than five years ago. Together, they successfully established the business.

Today, she continues to look for new market niches in other business projects, such as preparing and selling packaged ceviches. She is taking the first steps in this new branch of her business with her older son.

In ice cream sales, her main clients are small grocery and convenience stores throughout the province of Heredia. She runs her route three times per week to sell her product. In her ceviche business, she would be another provider of the prepared, packed product to sell it to a consolidated company called Lima Fish, which sells prepared foods to small restaurant businesses in the Heredia and Alajuela free trade zones. It is her older son's company. Mireidy is convinced that the quality of the product and the experience she gained working occasionally with her son would allow her to make a quality, competitive product and become established in the market. When she starts to focus on making ceviches, she and her son plan to make a contract stating that she will be in charge of supplying two of the restaurants from the existing client list. She has already planned how she would combine both businesses, since she does not plan to abandon her well established business selling ice cream with her business partner.

Mireidy washes all recyclables and takes them to the community childcare center, which sells them to raise money for their services to the community.

This new loan is Mireidy's opportunity to enter into a new business, while developing an existing one, all in the interest of improving her quality of life, continuing to support her son so that he can complete his higher education, and starting her savings for a future retirement for her husband and, of course, for herself.

loans.use: to buy ice cream and supplies and groceries for preparing ceviches.

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is 42 years old and married with five children. With four children in school, Pamela works very hard to provide for them.

Pamela runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Pamela has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, noodles and other groceries.

In the future, Pamela would like to save money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica is 43 years old and has five children. With four children in school, Jessica works very hard to provide for them.

Jessica runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 8,000 loan through NWTF to purchase items to sell, such as canned goods, beverages, home care products, and other groceries.

Jessica has been in this business for 5 years and sells a variety of items.

In the future, Jessica would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell, such as canned goods, beverages, home care products, and other groceries.

loans.name: Florida

texts.en:
Florida is 29 years old and married with five children. With four children in school, Florida works very hard to provide for them.

Florida has a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 8,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy more groceries to sell.

Florida has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items such as soap, shampoo, canned goods and other groceries.

In the future, Florida would like to save money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Norlyn

texts.en:
Norlyn is 38 years old and married with two children. With two children still in school, Norlyn works very hard to provide for them.

Norlyn runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 7,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her store, such as canned goods, noodles, spices, milk, coffee, drinks, eggs, bread and other snack foods.

Norlyn has been in this business for 8 years.

In the future, Norlyn would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her store, such as canned goods, noodles, spices, milk, coffee, drinks, eggs, bread and other snack foods.

loans.name: Miller

texts.en:
Miller signed up for his membership with PMPC and obtained the needed capital to start up a sari-sari store. He is thankful for the capital that was extended to a small-time borrower like him. 

Miller has been able to turn the tide in his favor and is making good sales these days. He wants to take advantage of this good fortune. Recently, he requested a loan to restock his store with basic commodities, such as canned goods, oil, and soy sauce.

In the future, he hopes to build a decent home for his family.

loans.use: to restock his store, with items such as canned goods, oil, and soy sauce.

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina is a strong-willed woman who pushes her ability when it comes to her piggery business. She is a hands-on businesswoman and mother who never gets tired of supporting her family. 

Recently, Carolina availed a loan to purchase bags of animal feed. Aside from her project of concreting the pig pens, she thought of adding heads of pigs for commercial sale. She someday hopes to open a meat shop in a nearby town.

loans.use: to purchase bags of animal feed.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita has availed of several loans in the past that helped sustain her tailoring business. She has also proven that she's consistent in repaying her previous loans. She's inspired by the way CCT, Kiva and its generous lenders extend their support to small entrepreneurs like her. Because of this, she's encouraged all the more to improve her tailoring and food vending business.

Once again, she's knocking at your kind hearts for a loan worth PHP 20,000, which she will use to buy additional supplies of fabric, thread, and other tailoring accessories. Some schools and companies are using her services for the needed costumes for their upcoming Christmas parties. She anticipates higher income from this.

Part of the loan will be used to sustain her food vending endeavor through additional raw ingredients, such as meat, fish, veggies, rice, spices and condiments. She gives her best effort to render the best service to her loyal and increasing customers.

Teresita dreams of expanding her tailoring shop so she can help her grandchildren in their schooling. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which she studies.

*All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional supplies of fabric, thread, and other tailoring accessories and additional raw ingredients such as meat, fish, veggies, rice, spices and condiments.

loans.name: Phearin

texts.en:
Phearin is a 21-year-old, single student who is from the Kampong Chhnang Province of Cambodia. He is pursuing a bachelor’s degree, majoring in finance and banking. He is currently in his first year of study at university in the city. 

Phearin's parents are rice farmers and practice animal husbandry. Due to a shortage of finances, Phearin has decided to secure a loan to pay his tuition fees from the first to fourth year of study. 

With this loan, Phearin will graduate successfully with the skills he needs for his future job. After graduation, Phearin is going to find a good job with a reasonable salary, and therefore he will be able to build a proper house.

loans.use: to pay his tuition fees for his first to fourth year of study.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma landed at the right place for her needed capital when she joined PMPC. She knew this would be her last chance to get back on her feet when she went broke after her first business went bad. PMPC came as a rescue to Norma by lending her money when she needed it the most.

Now, she availed another loan for the next cropping season. She borrowed an amount for land and seedbed preparation. Norma perseveres and always believes she can reach her goals to continually provide for her family.

loans.use: to pay for land and seedbed preparation

loans.name: Pulot

texts.en:
Pulot is a man with a kind heart. He lives with his family in a village. As with many local people, Pulot has been busy with animal husbandry. He feeds cows in his house where he has a big cowshed. Pulot grows the feed for the cows in his orchard. He has worked in this field for more than 10 years, and has great experience. 

Pulot is going to increase the number of cows he feeds. With this aim, he is asking for a loan of 1,350 USD to buy cows. He will improve his business and using the profits, make better his family's living conditions. He awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy cows for increasing his working capital.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is a 30-year-old woman who has three children, two of whom are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Jocelyn has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for three years. Jocelyn has requested an 8,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell.

In the future, Jocelyn would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana is 57 years old, married, and has ten children, one of whom is in school.

Susana is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Susana has been raising pigs for six years now, and has borrowed 11 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Susana would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Shaista

texts.en:
Shaista is 35-year-old married woman. She is the responsible mother of three children. She lives in the area of Lahore, Pakistan.

Her husband has been driving a taxi for 15 years. He is responsible for providing for the needs of the entire family.

Her husband needs to maintain his taxi because it is in poor condition. It requires more maintenance charges on daily basis. But he does not have sufficient financial means to maintain the vehicle.

Therefore Shaista has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner, BRAC Pakistan. With the help of this loan, Shaista's husband can afford the maintenance cost easily. He can provide better transport and earn a profitable income.

Shaista also plans to save some of her husband's profit to meet her family's needs in the future. She is very grateful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to help her husband to repair his taxi.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa is 47 years old, married, and lives in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. As a micro-finance member of Paglaum MPC, she is given priority in financial services to alleviate her present financial conditions with the necessary financial literacy and other training in which she actively participated.

Elsa saw the changes in her general living condition from the moment she signed up for membership with the cooperative. This time, she asks for a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase materials for boat making such as lumber, plywood, bronze nails, sealant, paint, bamboo, a boat engine, and fishing nets.

loans.use: to purchase materials for boat making such as lumber, plywood, bronze nails, sealant, paint, bamboo, a boat engine, and fishing nets.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 30 years old and married with five children. She lives in Lapasan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. To make a living, Grace operates a family member's business providing motor transport services. Aside from this, she also engages in raising pigs for sale. 

Grace joined GDMPC and availed a previous loan to purchase feed for livestock, which she successfully repaid. Recently, she borrowed a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase a new set of spare parts for the motor repair business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for motor repair.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is a hardworking entrepreneur with three children.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy a new engine for her fishing boat.

She industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like fattening pigs.

Edna dreams that one day, she will be able to save enough money to improve her family's quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a new engine for her fishing boat.

loans.name: Jacquelyn

texts.en:
Jacquelyn is a married woman with four children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Jacquelyn is 31 years old, and two of her children are in school.

Jacquelyn has a rice-vending business in the Philippines. Jacquelyn requested a PHP 5,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy additional sacks of rice to sell.

Jacquelyn has been in this business for one year. In the future, Jacquelyn would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn is 44 years old, married, and has one child.

She is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pig.

Roselyn has been in this business for three years now, and has borrowed seven times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Roselyn would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pig

loans.name: Mushgoa Multipurpose Self Help Group

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand (wearing a blue blouse) is Hannah, a member of Mushgoa Multipurpose Self Help Group. She is 41 years old, married, and blessed with five children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013 and she has been trained in enterprise development and financial management.

She farms potatoes, cabbages, kale, and dairy. She is taking a Kiva loan to buy fertilizer and certified seeds so as to improve her farming and meet her customers' demands. She says that this will help her generate more income from the farming activities.

Hannah is happy for Kiva and their lenders and promises to pay the loan well.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and certified seeds so as to improve productivity and meet customers' demands.

loans.name: Carmen Elaine

texts.es:
Carmen vive junto a su esposo y dos hijas en la ciudad de Santo Domingo, sector conocido en el país por ser una ciudad comercial y muy productiva; todo esto porque es una zona con un clima cálido húmedo y además porque es la ciudad donde se unen las regiones del país.
Carmen comenta que ha trabajado muy duro para poder sacar a su familia adelante, hace años atrás vivía en España junto a su esposo, tuvo que dejar a sus hijos al cuidado de familiares; se vieron en la necesidad de viajar porque en aquella época la economía estaba muy dura y se les hacía muy difícil mantener a sus hijos; ya hace 8 años decidieron regresar pero no por ello pudieron recuperar el tiempo perdido con sus pequeños ahora ya unos jóvenes, Carmen y su esposo han podido darle todo el amor posible. Desde ese entonces Carmen no quiso separarse más de sus hijos, por ello comenzó con un negocio desde casa, preparaba empanas y corviques, negocio que lo lleva hasta la actualidad, gracias a esos ingresos uno de sus hijos terminó el colegio y además pudo montarse una pequeña tienda. Está feliz que pese a que no generen muchos ingresos ella siempre está pendiente de su familia y trabajando; su esposo también le ayuda haciendo fletes en una pequeña camioneta que tiene.
Carmen con este crédito que pudo obtener podrá comprar más arroz, aceite, colas, y demás necesarios para su tiendita, además comprará una mesas con sillas para adecuar su negocio de empanadas y la gente se pueda servir con mejor comodidad.
Está muy agradecida con KIVA porque con este crédito está segura de que progresará y luego podrá ir creciendo de a poco de la mano de su familia.
texts.en:
Carmen lives together with her husband and two children in the city of Santo Domingo, that is known in the country for being a commercial city and being very productive. All this because it is an area with a hot humid climate and also as it is a city that unites the different regions of the country.

Carmen comments that she has worked very hard to get her family ahead. A number of years ago she lived in Spain with her husband and she had to leave her children in the care of family. They needed to travel as at that time the economy was very difficult and it was hard to support their children. Eight years ago they decided to return but they couldn't make up the lost time as their little ones had become adolescents. Carmen and her husband have given them all the love possible.

Since then Carmen doesn't want to be separated more from her children so she started a business from her house making empanadas and corviques (another local baked food). She has run this business up to now and thanks to this income one of her children has completed secondary school and she also managed to open a small store. She is happy even though she doesn't generate much income she can take care of the family and work. Her husband also helps making deliveries in a small van that he has.

Carmen with this loan she was awarded can buy more rice, oil, soft drinks and other necessities for her store. She also will buy some tables with chairs to outfit her empanada business so her clients can be served in greater comfort.

Carmen is very grateful to Kiva as with this loan she is certain she can progress and later continue to grow a little hand in hand with her family.

loans.use: to buy basic need food products like rice, oil, soft drinks and stock her store.

loans.name: Jenie

texts.en:
Jenie has a collection of ornamental garden plants. She finds pleasure in doing her gardening activities and earns as well for her family.

As a micro-finance member of PMPC, she has sought financial help to purchase a variety of ornamental plants that she can grow and sell. In the future, Jenie wishes to become the supplier of flowers in the neighboring towns.

loans.use: to purchase variety of ornamental plants that she can grow and sell

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma is a microfinance member of PMPC. She is 55 years old, married, and has a snack fishing business in Calamba. This is how she supports her family with a meager income of PHP 5,000 per month.

Recently, Wilma availed a loan to purchase plywood, nails, and sticks for her house. She wants to improve her family's living conditions and maintain her membership with the Cooperative.

loans.use: to purchase plywood, nails, and sticks for her house

loans.name: Rose Mae

texts.en:
Rose Mae is 24 years old and married with one child.

She has a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 8,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Rose Mae has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items such as snack food, canned goods, and other groceries.

In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Loregil

texts.en:
Loregil is a married woman with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur who is 29 years old and has two children who are in school.

She has a fish vending business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy variety of fish to sell.

Loregil has been in this business for two years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy variety of fish to sell

loans.name: Nillie

texts.en:
Nillie is 62 years old. She is known in the Calamba, Misamis Occidental, area for her sari-sari (variety) store. She is actively participating in the various programs and services that the co-op offers.

She hopes to live comfortably, with a decent house, for which she applied for a loan to purchase plywood, nails, and sticks. She hopes to maintain her membership in good standing, with a good repayment record. It matters that she has been given a priority as a microfinance member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC). This is what she is thankful for, when all her financing needs of her retailing business are supported by PMPC.

loans.use: to purchase plywood, nails, and sticks for her house.

loans.name: Gavina

texts.en:
Gavina has been running a nursery business in Villaflor, Oroquieta City. She is 60 years old and married with adult children who help her with her business venture.

Her business is supported by her loans from PMPC so that she can respond to the demand of her immediate market. Recently, she took a loan to buy more falkata seeds (commonly grown trees for plywood production) for her nursery business.

loans.use: to buy more falkata seeds (commonly grown trees for plywood production) for her nursery business.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is a married man. He has four children. He describes himself to be honest. He operates a carpentry business where he makes furniture. He has been involved in this business for three years. His primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

He will use the KES 100,000 loan to buy more stock of carpentry materials. His business goal is to own a big hardware within five years.

This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loans were repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy more stock of carpentry materials
